paragraph.paragraph:
A Conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point is a
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point that will only halt the execution of the system when a specific condition is met.

You may turn any regular
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point into conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point by modifying its properties. The properties of the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreakPoint are accessed through the Breakpoint Properties dialog, accessed by right clicking on a
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreakPoint representation, often in the editor or the breakpoint window, and selecting BreakpointProperties... from the context menu.

The top half of the dialog displays read only information regarding the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreakPoint , corresponding to its position in the source code. The buttons Condition... and HitCount.. both display dialogs which allow you to specify the condition, or the hit count for the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreakPoint , turning it into a conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point .
paragraph.heading: 2Break Point Condition
paragraph.paragraph:
This dialog allows you to specify a condition that must be satisfied for the execution of the system to stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point .
BreakPoint Condition BreakPointCondition.png
The condition may be contain any of the
0 Eiffel argument !DefaultAssociativeIndexarguments , locals or
0 Eiffel attribute !DefaultAssociativeIndexattributes of the
0 Eiffel routine !DefaultAssociativeIndexroutine in which the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel break pointsBreak Point is defined. Current is also a valid item for the expression, and when the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutine has a Result, then Result is valid in the expression.

Item at index, applies only to arrays.
The @ symbol is used to access an array, so for example, if there was a local attribute that was an array, you could access the fifth element as follows:
my_array @ 5
You may also qualify the condition with either is true or has changed:
Is True - Stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point when the expression evaluates to True.
Has Changed - Stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point when the result of evaluating the expression changes.
A
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point condition may also be combined with a hit count if necessary.
2Break Point Hit Count
This dialog allows you to specify a hit count for the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point . A hit count specifies the number of times that the breakpoint must be reached before theexecution will stop. If you also have a condition on the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndexBreak Point , then the current hit count will only be incremented if the condition is satisfied.
There are four options available for the condition of the hit count:
Break always
Break when the hit count is equal to
Break when the hit count is a multiple of
Break when the hit count is greater than or equal to
And you may adjust the value for the comparison, which must be an integer value.
